facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 428 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 428 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 25, 1959 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 47-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 25, 1959, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 47-D of 1955,

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 47-D of 1955 arising out of judgment dated November 28, 1955 of Punjab High Court in Writ Petition No. 306-D of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated November 28, 1955 of the said High Court in Writ Petition No. 306-D of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 19, 1960 by WanchOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. January 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-

facts.text: Appellant granted mining lease by Ruler of Gangpur State on December 30, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was granted a mining lease by the then Ruler of Gangpur State on December 30, 1947, shortly before the merger of that State with the State of Orissa on January 1, 1948.

facts.text: Merger of Gangpur State with State of Orissa on January 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was granted a mining lease by the then Ruler of Gangpur State on December 30, 1947, shortly before the merger of that State with the State of Orissa on January 1, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant's lease annulled on June 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This lease was annulled on June 29, 1949. Thereafter the appellant was granted certificates of approval in respect of prospecting licences and mining leases.

facts.text: Appellant applied on December 19, 1949 for mining leases for manganese in five areas in Sundergarh, Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, the appellant applied on December 19, 1949, for mining leases for manganese in respect of five areas in the district of Sundergarh  Orissa .

facts.text: Appellant asked on July 4, 1950 to submit separate application for each area.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked on July 4, 1950, to submit a separate application for each area which he did on July 27, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant submitted separate applications on July 27, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked on July 4, 1950, to submit a separate application for each area which he did on July 27, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant submitted fresh applications on September 6, 1950 after removing defects.

anchor.surface_text: Some defects were pointed out in these applications and therefore the appellant submitted fresh applications on September 6, 1950, after removing the defects.

facts.text: Third respondent made applications for mining leases for manganese for the same areas on July 10, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the third respondent also made applications for mining leases for manganese for the same area on July 10, 1950.

facts.text: Third respondent's applications not accompanied by deposit required under r.29.

anchor.surface_text: These applications were number accompanied by the deposit required under r. 29 of the Rules.

facts.text: Third respondent asked on July 24, 1950 to deposit Rs.500, deposited on August 3, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the third respondent was asked on July 24, 1950, to deposit a sum of Rs. 500, which it did on August 3, 1950.

facts.text: Third respondent's applications found defective, asked on September 5, 1950 to send separate applications, submitted on September 6, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It was then found that the third respondents applications were defective. It was therefore asked on September 5, 1950, to send a separate application in the prescribed form for each block and thereupon it submitted fresh applications on September 6, 1950.

facts.text: State of Orissa granted mining leases of five areas to appellant on December 22, 1952 based on r.32 priority as appellant's applications prior.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, on December 22, 1952, the State of Orissa granted the mining leases of the five areas to the appellant taking into account r. 32 of the Rules, which prescribed priority.

facts.text: Possession of leased areas delivered to appellant on April 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on April 21, 1953, possession of the areas leased was delivered to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant put in possession and actually worked the areas thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1953 the appellant was put in possession of the areas granted to him and actually worked them thereafter.

facts.text: Third respondent applied for review to Central Government under r.52.

anchor.surface_text: It seems, however, that the third respondent had applied for review to the Central Government under r. 52 of the Rules.

facts.text: Central Government allowed review application on January 28, 1954 and directed Government of Orissa to grant mining lease to third respondent for two out of five areas.

anchor.surface_text: This review application was allowed by the Central Government on January 28, 1954, and the Government of Orissa was directed to grant a mining lease to the third respondent with respect to two out of the five areas.

facts.text: Appellant came to know in February 1954 that third respondent had applied for review.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companyplaint is that he came to know in February, 1954, that the third respondent had applied to the Central Government under r. 52 for review.

facts.text: Appellant addressed letter to Central Government praying for hearing before order on review application.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon addressed a letter to the Central Government praying that he might be given a hearing before any order was passed on the review application.

facts.text: Appellant informed on July 5, 1955 by Government of Orissa of Central Government order dated January 28, 1954 cancelling lease for two areas.

anchor.surface_text: He was, however, informed on July 5, 1955, by the Government of Orissa of the order passed by the Central Government on January 28, 1954, by which the lease granted to him by the State of Orissa with respect to two areas was cancelled.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court (No. 306-D of 1954) seeking quashing of Central Government order dated January 28, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, he made an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the Punjab High Court praying for quashing the order of January 28, 1954, on the ground that it was a quasi-judicial order and the rules of natural justice had number been followed...

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court held Central Government order administrative, not quasi-judicial, writ petition failed.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was heard by a learned Single Judge of the High Court and it was held that the order was number a quasi-judicial order but merely an administrative one...

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court upheld Single Judge order in Letters Patent Appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went up in Letters Patent Appeal to a Division Bench of the High Court, which upheld the order of the learned Single Judge.

facts.text: Punjab High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal upon a certificate granted by the Punjab High Court raises the question...

issues.text: whether an order of the Central Government under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, is quasi-judicial or administrative

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether an order of the Central Government under r. 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949, hereinafter called the Rules framed under s. 6 of the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, No. 53 of 1941, hereinafter called the Act is quasi- judicial or administrative.

issues.text: whether the order of January 28, 1954 was a quasi-judicial order and the rules of natural justice had not been followed inasmuch as no hearing was given before the review application was allowed

issues.text: whether the Central Government was acting in a quasi-judicial capacity under r. 54 and therefore required to hear the appellant before deciding the review application, and whether failure to do so contravened principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Shri N. C. Chatterji appearing on behalf of the appellant contends that the Central Government was acting in a quasi- judicial capacity when it passed the order under r. 54 of the Rules and therefore it was incumbent upon it to hear the appellant before deciding the review application, and inasmuch as it did not do so it contravened the principles of natural justice which apply in such a case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 52-55 create statutory right to review generating lis between grantee and aggrieved party; precedents establish duty to act judicially where lis exists and authority determines rights; r.55 renders state order final subject to review; nothing contrary in rules.

holdings.text: there is prima facie a lis in this case as between the person to whom the lease has been granted and the person who is aggrieved by the refusal and therefore prima facie it is the duty of the authority which has to review the matter to act judicially

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is prima facie a lis in this case as between the person to whom the lease has been granted and the person who is aggrieved by the refusal and therefore prima facie it is the duty of the authority which has to review the matter to act judicially and there is nothing in r. 54 to the contrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.52 grants aggrieved party right to review state refusal, creating dispute with successful grantee; precedents dictate judicial duty prima facie upon lis unless statute provides otherwise.

holdings.text: there is nothing in the Rules which negatives the duty to act judicially by the reviewing authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial proceedings require observance of natural justice, including hearing affected parties in lis.

holdings.text: In as much as this was not done, the appellant is entitled to ask us to issue a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing the order of January 28,1954, passed by the Central Government.

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Bora and another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra Nath Bora and another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam and others 1 , and submits that rr. 52 to 55 of the Rules which are relevant for the purpose clearly show that the proceeding before the Central Government is a quasi-judicial proceeding

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: rr. 52 to 55 of the Rules clearly show that the proceeding before the Central Government is a quasi-judicial proceeding in view of statutory right to review, limitation period, fee, and creation of lis

precedents.citation: Province of Bombay v. Kushaldas S. Advani 1

anchor.surface_text: Province of Bombay v. Kushaldas S. Advani 1 , it adopted the celebrated definition of a quasi-judicial body given by Atkin L. J. in R. v. Electricity Commissioners 2 , which is as follows- Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects

precedents.case_name: Province of Bombay v. Kushaldas S. Advani
precedents.cited_proposition: definition and principles for determining whether an authority's act is quasi-judicial
precedents.cited_holding: That, if a statute empowers an authority, not being a Court in the ordinary sense, to decide disputes arising out of a claim made by any party under the statute which claim is opposed by another party and to determine the respective rights of contesting parties who are opposed to each other, there is a lis and prima facie ... it is the duty of the authority to act judicially ... ; and that if a statutory authority has power to do any act which will prejudicially affect the subject ... the final determination of the authority will yet be a quasi-judicial act provided the authority is required by the statute to act judicially.

anchor.surface_text: R. v. Electricity Commissioners 2 , which is as follows- Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench Division exercised in these writs.

precedents.cited_holding: Whenever any body of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting rights of subjects, and having the duty to act judicially act in excess of their legal authority they are subject to the controlling jurisdiction of the Kings Bench Division exercised in these writs.
